The Makololo expressed great
satisfaction with 'the route to the West we had opened up
and soon after our arrival a Picho was called in order to discuss
'the question of removal to 'the Barotse valley in order ^ so that they might to be nearer
'the market Some of 'the older men objected to abandoning 'the line
`of defence afforded by 'the river Chobe and ZambesiZambezi against their
southern enemies the Matebele The Makololo ^ generally have
an aversion to 'the Barotse valley because ^ on account of 'the fevers wh.which are
annually engendered in it as 'the waters dry up They prefer
it ^ only as a cattle station, for though 'the herds are frequently thinned
by an epidemic disease (peripneumonia) they breed so fast
that 'the losses are soon replaced made good. Wherever ^ else 'the Makololo
go they always leave a portion `of their stock in 'the charge `of herdsmen
in ^ that prolific valley Some of 'the younger men objected to removal
because 'the rankness of 'the grass at 'the Barotse did not allow `of their
running fast and because there "it never becomes cool"
Sekeletu at last stood up and addressing me said "I am
perfectly satisfied as to 'the great advantages ` 'of the path for trade
wh.which you have opened and think that we ought to go to 'the Barotse
in order to make 'the way ^ from us to LoandaLuanda shorter but with whom am I to live there?
ifIf you were coming ^ with us I would remove tomorrow but now you
are going to 'the white man's country to bring Ma Robert and when
you return you will find me near to 'the spot on whwhich you wish
to dwell" I had then no idea that any healthy spot
existed in 'the country and thought only `of a convenient central
situation adapted for intercourse with 'the adjacent tribes and
with 'the coast such as that near to 'the confluence ` 'of the Leeba & Leeambye

The fever is certainly a drawback to this otherwise important
missionary field The great humidity produced by heavy rains
with 'the exception of sugarless coffee

for Him who came down from heaven and died for us, but I

I believe that the Interior of this country presents a
much more inviting field for the Philanthropist
than does the West coast where missionaries
of the church missionaryChurch Missionary ^ United Presbyterian & other societies have
long laboured with the most marvellousastonishing devoted-
ness and ^ never flagging zeal - There the fevers are much
more virulent thanand & more speedily fatal
than here - for from 8° South they
almost invariably take on allthe intermittent
^ type and their effect isbeing to enlarge the spleen
which ^ a complaint ^ which is ofbest treated by
a change of climate which ^ & that we have
at hand on passing the 20° parallel
on our way South - But I am not to
be understood as intimating that any of the
numerous tribes are anxious tofor instruction
They are not the enquiring spirits we read
of in other countries they do not desire
the gospel because they know nothing about
^ it or its benefits - But there is no
impediment in the way of civilization
instruction - Every headman in the
country would be proud of any European
visitor or resident in his countryterritory
for there and there is perfect security
for life and property all over the
country - The great barriers which
have kept Africa shut are the unhealthiness
of the coast and the exclusive, illiberal
disposition of the coastborder tribes - They
latter would be ^ prove but a small obstacles
in It is to be hoped theyat ^ these obstacles will be overcome
by the more rapid means of locomotion
possessed by the present age if a good
highway can be found intofrom the coast
into the Interior

Some recommended my going to Sesheke and crossing over in

Others recommended to go on 'the south bank ` 'of the ZambesiZambezi

In pondering over these difficult paths I could not help regretting
my being alone If I had enjoyed 'the company `of my former com-
panion Mr Oswell one `of us might have taken 'the ZambesiZambezi and
'the other gone by way `of Zanzibar The latter route was decidedly

Being near 'the ^ end of September the rains were expected daily the clouds were col-

strongly to remain till 'the ground should be cooled by 'the rains and
as it was probable that wI should get fever if I commenced my
journey now I resolved to wait Some idea may be formed
of 'the eatheat in OctOctober by 'the fact that 'the thermometer stood in 'the shade of my waggon
at 100° through the day If unprotected ^ from the wind it rose to 110° — at dark it
showed 89° at 10 oclko'clock 80° then gradually sinks till sunrise when
it iswas 70° That is usually 'the period of greatest cold for in this region I have
seen on many occasions the thermometer fall a few degrees just
as 'the sunssun's rays began to shoot across 'the atmosphere The natives
during 'the period of greatest heat keep in their huts wh.which are always
pleasantly cool by day but close and suffocating by night
Those who are able to afford it sit guzzling beer or boyaloa
The perspiration produced by copious draughts seem to give enjoyment
or the evaporation causing a feeling of coolness. The attendants of
'the chief on these occasions keep up a continuous roar of banteringchafing
raileryraillery and laughing ^ & swearing In the moon light nights the dance is
kept up till past midnight The women stand clapping
their hands continuously and 'the old men sit admiringly and say
"It is really very fine" I employed much of my time
in conversation as that is a good mode of conveying instruction
In the public meetings for worship the people listened very
attentively and behaved with more decorum than formerly
It seems is really a very worthy field for ^ a missionary labours
Surely 'the oft told tale of 'the goodness and love of our heavenly Father in
giving up his own Son to death for us sinners will beget love
in some of these heathen hearts.

Relatives alone will condescend to touch a dead body
It would be easy to enumerate instances of inhumanity which
I have witnessed An interesting looking girl came to my
waggon one day in a state of nudity and almost a skeleton
She was a captive from another tribe and had been neglected
by 'the man who claimed her - having supplied her wants I made
enquiry for him 'the man who claimed her and found that he had been
unsuccessful in raising a crop of corn and had no food to
give her I volunteered to take her but he said he would
allow me to feed her and make her fat and then take her away
I protested against this heartlessness and as he said he could not

If we take a glance back at the great valley
the form the rivers have taken imparts the
idea at once of a Lake slowly drained out
for they have cut out for themselves
beds exactly like what we may see in
the soft mud of shallow pool of rain
water when that is let off by a furrow
This idea would probably not strike a person
on coming first into the country but more
extensive acquaintance with the river system
certainly would convey the idea – None of
the rivers in the valley of the Leeambye
have slopes down to their beds – Indeed
many parts are much like the Thames
at the "Isle of Dogs" only the Leeambye
has to rise twenty or thirty feet before
it can overflow its meadows - They rivers
have each a bed of low water which
is simply a furrow cut sharply out of
a bed of calcareous tufa which
lined the bed of the ancient Lake, and
another of inundation - When Thethe beds
of inundation are filled they assume
the appearance of chains of Lakes
The rest of the country is generally
not elevated fifty feet above these
When the Clyde fills the holms (haughs)
above Bothwell bridge it has untutored ^
the appearance and retires again
into its bed it resembles the
river we are speaking of only
hthere there are no high lands

Although 'the Makololo were so confiding the
reader must not imagine that they would be so to every
individual who might visit them Much of my influence
depended upon a good name given me by 'the Bakwains and
that I did not secured only through a long course of tolerably

country without purity and uprightness The acts of a
stranger are keenly scrutinized by both young and old and

or uncharitable I have heard women speaking in admiration
of a missionary ^ white man because he was pure and never was guilty of any
secret immorality hadHad he been they would have known it and
